ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book The Greatest Adventure. We learned about Eliot, and how he wanted to go on a real adventure. He dreamed of adventures on the high seas and tracking wild beasts.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit Vocabulary We learned the word adventure . Let’s revisit that word since that has something to do with today’s activity. Show the adventure Vocabulary Card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk: In this activity, we will look at pictures of people on real adventures. We’ll talk about where each adventure is.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show the first picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Adventures Ask children which card shows an adventure they would like to go on. What would they do? Compare children’s responses to elicit a comparison of the different environments.
Talk About Places Have children discuss the different environments shown in the cards. How would the clothes they wear be different in each one?
Check children’s understanding by asking questions about the differences in the environments. Encourage children to respond in complete, grammatically correct sentences.

Ask children who can more easily distinguish the environments to describe what they would take with them on an adventure in each location. What’s the most important thing they might need in the desert? In the woods? In the ocean?

section-block.ac_mod_teacher-card_d_hed: Multilingual Learners: Different Dialects and Expressions
section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Children will look at pictures of adventures all around the country. Explain that English speakers can have different words and expressions that refer to the same thing. Sometimes you may not understand a word that someone says even when the word is in your own language. For example, some people use the word soda, others say pop. Ask children if they can speak more than one language and what that language is.

Have children act out an adventure in one of the locations shown on the cards. Encourage children to use large body movements to represent, for example, holding the sails of a boat against a strong wind, or climbing a steep path on a mountain trail. Movement helps activate memory as it makes the activity more stimulating.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need the book The Greatest Adventure for reference in this activity.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book The Greatest Adventure. We learned how Eliot persisted so he could have an adventure on his grandfather’s boat. Eliot never gave up.
When we persist in a task, it means we don’t give up.

Yesterday we looked at pictures of different adventures—hiking in the woods, sailing on a boat, snorkeling in the ocean. Today we are going to think of the greatest adventure that we have gone on, where we were, and the things we did there!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach/Model Ask children to describe adventures they have gone on in their lives and what they liked (or didn’t like) about the adventure.
Ask Show pages 26–29 from the book to show Eliot’s persistence.
section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: What adventure did you go on?
Did you have to persist, or not give up, in order to have an adventure?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk: Earlier today, we talked about how important it is to persist in a task or something you want to do. At first it can be hard, but if we persist and keep at it, we can get there at the end.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About Adventures Have children discuss the different types of adventures they talked about. Are any of them related adventures? Would anyone like to go on an adventure their classmate went on?
Some children may have a hard time coming up with an adventure on their own. Encourage them to describe an adventure they would like to go on instead.
For children needing a bit more, challenge them to act out their adventure as they tell their story. Where was it? What type of activities did they do on their adventure?

Young children are usually better at learning a new language than adults. Adults may be afraid that they will say something incorrectly in English. On the other hand, young children are less inhibited and willing to take risks. Create a stress-free environment in which children enjoy trying out new words and phrases, one where their home language and English are both celebrated.
Offer children the option to draw a response to the activity using pencils, crayons, or markers. Encourage children to talk as they draw, using as many describing words as possible.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book The Greatest Adventure. We learned how Eliot liked to pretend to track the trails of wild beasts.
We learned the word wild. Let’s revisit that word since that has something to do with today’s activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show the wild Vocabulary Card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures of different animals and sort the picture cards into two groups:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Group 1 is Wild Animals. Wild animals live outdoors all the time, and they are not cared for by people.
Group 2 is Not Wild Animals. These animals often live indoors, where people take care of them.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Explain that farm animals are not wild because people take care of them even if the animals don’t live inside with people.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show the first picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity with all of the cards.
Talk About Wild Animals Discuss places where wild animals live. Ask, How do wild animals take care of themselves?
Talk About Safety Explain that it is important not to approach a wild animal if you see one.

Show children three picture cards at once in a group in which one is an example of a wild animal and the other two are not wild. Ask: Which one doesn’t belong? Then ask: How do you know? Repeat with other groups of three cards.

Show children two picture cards at a time, where one is an example of a wild animal and the other is not. Ask: What is the same and what is different about these animals? Repeat with other pairs of cards.

Give children extra time for peer-to-peer conversation. Encourage children to work in pairs, discussing whether or not an animal is wild. Remind them to take turns speaking, with one person actively listening while the other speaks. Remind children that it’s okay to use all the languages they both know when talking with a peer who is also multilingual.

To help children who may have difficulty remembering the names of all the different animals, have children act out how the animals move and how they sound. Using the body can help trigger muscle memory and aid in recall.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the informational poster I Want To... We talked about what we want to learn and what we want to be able to do. We also talked about what we want to be when we grow up.

In this activity, we will look at pictures of adults doing different jobs. We will figure out what kind of job the person in the picture has, and we’ll talk about what that person does. We’ll also talk about if we think that’s a job that we might like to have one day when we grow up.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show the first picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the rest of the picture cards.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All the pictures show people working at different jobs. What other jobs can you name? Which jobs do you think you would you like to have when you grow up? Why?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About What They Need to Learn Ask children what they might need to learn to do each job.
Review each picture card with children before you begin. Make sure children can identify the job represented on the card.
Ask children to choose their favorite job from those listed on the cards. Have them explain why they chose the job. What is it that they like most about it?
Help native Spanish speakers make the connection between the words police officer and oficial de policia. You may wish to talk about the close connection between English and Spanish terms.

For children who have fine-motor development difficulties, provide a play space where children can pretend to be an artist or a doctor using tools like a small paintbrush or a stethoscope. Encourage creative play but include the use of pretend or toy tools to represent the motions needed. As children act out the tasks, have them use terms that describe the job and the tools to reinforce the vocabulary.
